did.unittitle: Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 10 record cartons and 1 manuscript box.

did.abstract: Teamsters for a Democratic Union was formed in the 1970s by rank-and-file members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to combat corruption in their union. The New York - New Jersey regional office of the TDU was established in 1987. Materials include administrative records of the TDU, materials related to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, records pertaining to Teamsters locals, records related to divisions within the union, individual grievances, legal records, correspondence, resource materials, and photographs.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Teamsters for a Democratic Union. New York - New Jersey Chapter.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are organized into nine series:

Series III: International Brotherhood of Teamsters Locals, 1961-1994

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The records were donated to the Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives by the Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter in February 1998 and in 2003.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The New York metropolitan region has one of the largest concentrations of Teamster members and local unions in the U.S. Over 100,000 Teamsters work in a huge range of industries in New York and New Jersey. New York has played an important part in the history of the International union.

In 1970 in New York City, a committed band of activists in Local 282 organized a dissident group, FORE - Fear of Reprisal Ends. They issued a newsletter, bulletins, ran election campaigns in their local, issued challenges to their corrupt leadership through the National Labor Relations Board and through the courts. They organized by addressing issues related to contracts, grievances, pension fund loans, etc. While a tiny minority within their 4,500 member local, they kept up the pressure on their union officials, many of whom eventually went to jail.

In 1975, the Teamsters for a Democratic Contract (TDC) was formed to pressure IBT President Frank Fitzsimmons into supporting certain demands in upcoming negotiations. Following an attack on a TDC member attending the 1976 national Teamster convention, an enlarged TDC became the Teamsters for a Democratic Union (TDU). The Convoy Dispatch, TDC’s national newspaper, continued its existence as the paper for the TDU. The reform group developed its greatest strength in the core jurisdictions of the IBT - freight trucking; carhauling; grocery delivery and United Parcel Service (UPS). In 1987-1988, TDU was able to organize three straight contract rejections - the UPS contract, the National Master Freight Agreement (NMFA), and the Carhaul (national) contract. The 80s posed a difficult set of problems for the reform group. With the balance of power shifting to the employers side due to de-regulation and a severe economic recession, it became more difficult to pull off militant actions. Local organizing efforts concentrated on basic educational, contractual, grievance, by-law reform campaigns and electoral activities.

In 1991, Ron Carey, head of New York’s Local 804, endorsed by TDU a full two years before the election, was elected as general president of the union in December 1991, winning 16 of the 17 spots on the IBT international executive board. Seven of Carey’s 16-member slate were members of TDU.

In 1996, with Carey running for a second term, the head of New York’s Joint Council 16, Anthony Rumore, officially stayed on the sidelines. Rumore, as president of the 130,000-member Council, was the most powerful Teamster in the East. “The so-called wiseguys got better contracts for the people than all the new white horses,” he said. But the “white horses,” despite turning out more than 200 reputed mobsters, and shaking up the union structurally and programmatically, were themselves turned out of office by government charges. The epic and systematic problems associated with the NY-NJ Teamsters continue. The New York-New Jersey metropolitan area poses particular problems. For the most part, teamsters are working in marginal industries and/or companies that have long suffered under substandard Teamster contracts. Minorities form an increasingly large proportion of the membership. As David Pratt, staff organizer for the NY-NJ Chapter writes: “the fragmented, structural arrangement makes it extremely difficult for members to pool their resources and make changes in their locals. The battle for democracy is fought shop by shop and local by tiny local.”

“Rank-and-file Teamster Movements in Comparative Perspective,” by Aaron Brenner. Trade Union Politics: American Unions and Economic Change 1960s - 1990s. Edited by Glenn Perusek and Kent Worcester. New Jersey: Humanities Press, 1995.
“Where is the Teamster Rebellion Going?” by Staughton Lynd. Workers’ Struggles, Past and Present: A Radical America Reader. Edited by James Green. Philadelphia: Temple University Press, 1983.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records; WAG 136; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records includes administrative records of the TDU, materials related to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, records pertaining to Teamsters locals, records related to divisions within the union, individual grievances, legal records, correspondence, resource materials, and photographs.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Photographs were separated from this collection during initial processing and were established as a separate collection, the Teamsters for a Democratic Union Photographs (PHOTOS 170). In 2013, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:

did.unittitle: Series I: Organizational Records, 1965-1994

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series I includes TDU materials, including convention materials, steering committee notes, agendas, financial reports and organizing materials, rank and file flyers and campaign materials.

Series II: International Brotherhood of Teamsters Materials, 1968-1994

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of IBT materials collected by TDU. This includes material on the International’s by-laws and constitution; convention materials; contracts and supplemental agreements; pension materials; various government records required by the LMRDA and material published under the Ron Carey administration on women in the union.

Series III: International Brotherhood of Teamsters Locals, 1961-1994

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series III is arranged by Local numbers; the material relate to specific campaigns undertaken in those locals. Some records relate to pension fund campaigns and the efforts of TDU staff, in particular Susan Jennik to secure pension benefits for members. Additional materials include election records, mediation and arbitration awards; NLRB cases and grievance files; and collective bargaining. The records of Local 560, with its history of corruption and lengthy government-imposed trusteeship are of particular interest.

Series IV: Divisions, 1975-1988

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The materials in Series IV are divided as follows: Carhaul, Freight, and the National Master Freight Agreement. These records include materials from companies such as Roadway and Consolidated Freightways, two examples of national freight companies strengthened and emboldened by de-regulation.

Series VI: Legal, 1977-1994

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series VI is organized by court cases, many involving pension and benefit funds. The records also include materials from the government’s case against the international union, U.S. v. La Cosa Nostra. Individuals featured include Dellacroce and Salerno. Some material relates to Jackie Presser’s role as a government informant (see “Identity of Informant known as “Alpro.”) The records contain the settlement and documents pertaining to supervision of the first direct election in the union’s history. Materials developed by the TDU in preparation for the election are included in this series.

Series VII: Resource Materials, 1977-1995

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series VII consists of subject files related to the union and the industry, as well as generic materials on labor and the reform movement. Various rank-and-file groups are represented, including those in the Utility Workers, the CWA, (New Directions caucus) the UAW, postal employees, etc.

Series IX: Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series IX includes photographs, contact sheets, and negatives from the late 1970s through late 1980s. These images are mainly from the Detroit area and depict TDU leaders and activists and demonstrations.
